misconceptions.name: Reads two coordinate pairs instead of a single numeric grade
misconceptions.description: The program prompts for x/y coordinates and reads four doubles instead of reading a single numeric grade value between 0 and 100 as required by the grade calculator specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can reuse a distance-formula-style program that reads x1, y1, x2, y2 for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, the program should read exactly one numeric input representing a grade between 0 and 100 (e.g., using nextInt or nextDouble) after an appropriate prompt like "Enter grade:".
symptoms: Prompts are "Enter x1 and y1" and "Enter x2 and y2" instead of "Enter grade".
Program calls nextDouble four times instead of once.
No variable represents a grade value from 0 to 100.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have copied or repurposed a distance computation example instead of implementing the required grade input behavior.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the multiple coordinate inputs with a single grade input variable (e.g., double grade = INPUT.nextDouble();), and adjust the prompt to ask for a grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly reads four doubles labeled as coordinates and never reads a single grade value; there is no variable that could represent the required grade.

evidence.note: Instead of reading a single numeric grade, the program reads four double values representing two coordinate pairs.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional checks for A and B grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The program does not contain any conditional logic to test whether the numeric input falls into the A (90-100) or B (80-89) ranges, which is required to map a grade to a letter.
misconceptions.student_belief: I only need to compute and print the distance; no range-based decisions are necessary.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must use conditional statements (if/else-if) to check if the grade is between 90-100 for an A and between 80-89 for a B, and then print the corresponding letter.
symptoms: No if/else-if or boolean expressions in the program.
Only a single println that always outputs a distance value.
Letter grades A or B are never mentioned or printed.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a distance formula computation instead of a grade classification problem, so no boolean conditions for A or B were added.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an if/else-if chain that first checks if grade >= 90, else if grade >= 80, and so on, and prints 'A' or 'B' accordingly.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditional statements in the file and no letter-grade logic; the entire program is linear numeric computation.

evidence.note: After reading inputs, the code goes straight to arithmetic and printing; there are no if/else conditions to distinguish A and B ranges.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional checks for C and D grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The program fails to implement any conditions for the C (70-79) and D (60-69) grade ranges; it never branches based on a grade value.
misconceptions.student_belief: Computing and printing a single numeric result is sufficient; intermediate ranges do not need explicit handling.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should include boolean checks for the 70-79 and 60-69 ranges so that grades in these intervals are mapped to the letters C and D.
symptoms: No conditions or branching corresponding to grade ranges 70-79 or 60-69.
The word 'grade' or letters C/D do not appear anywhere in the code.
All executions follow a single path and produce a distance output.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely focused on replicating a known distance-formula solution and ignored the requirement to classify a grade into multiple ranges.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Extend the if/else-if chain to include conditions like 'else if (grade >= 70)' for C and 'else if (grade >= 60)' for D, ensuring non-overlapping ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no mention of C or D grading logic; the code never references grade ranges or conditional branches.

evidence.note: The variable set-up and overall program structure make no provision for any grade variable or branching for C/D ranges.

misconceptions.name: No default or else branch for failing grades (F)
misconceptions.description: There is no logic to handle the case where a grade is below 60 and should be mapped to an F; the program never considers such a default case.
misconceptions.student_belief: The problem does not require handling a default or 'otherwise' case because it is not treated as a classification task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should include an else branch that covers all remaining cases below 60 and outputs the letter 'F'.
symptoms: Absence of any else or default branch in the code.
Program never prints 'F' or any indication of failing status.
Behavior is identical regardless of input values; there is no classification.
misconceptions.root_cause: By not implementing any conditional chain at all, the student omitted the required catch-all else case for grades below 60.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After handling A, B, C, and D ranges with if/else-if, add a final 'else' that prints 'F' for any grade below 60.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to discrete categories
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Since there is no conditional logic of any kind, there cannot be a default else branch for F grades.

evidence.note: The final output always prints a distance; there is no else or fallback case that could serve as an F grade handler.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Outputs distance text instead of letter grades
misconceptions.description: The program prints a sentence about the distance between two points rather than printing a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) corresponding to the input grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The required output is the numeric distance between two points formatted as a sentence.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The output should be a letter grade corresponding to the numeric grade, e.g., 'Letter grade: B', not a distance description.
symptoms: Output text is "The distance of the two points is ...".
No mention of 'Letter grade:' or any single-letter grade output in the code.
Output is always a double value appended to a distance message.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a different problem (distance calculation) and did not adapt the output to show a letter grade.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After computing which range the grade falls into, print 'Letter grade: ' followed by 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D', or 'F' instead of a distance message.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only println clearly outputs a distance message, and there is no code that prints any letter grade.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + DISTANCE);
evidence.note: The printed message refers to distance between points rather than a letter grade as required.

misconceptions.name: Problem Misidentification
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that calculates the Euclidean distance between two points, which is a solution to a different problem, rather than the requested Grade Calculator program.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the submitted code fulfills the requirements of Question 3, likely due to submitting the wrong file or misreading the assignment prompt entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requirement for Q3 was to read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional logic to output a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Inputs are four coordinates (X1, Y1, X2, Y2) instead of one grade.
Program calculates mathematical distance using Math.sqrt() and prints a numeric result.
Missing all conditional logic (if/else statements) required for grade mapping.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely submitted the solution for a different question (e.g., Q1 or Q2) or copied the wrong template.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the requirements for Question 3 and implement the logic using Scanner to read the grade and if-else statements to map the grade to the required letter (A, B, C, D, or F).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code structure, variable names (X1, Y1, DX, DY, DISTANCE), calculation logic (Math.sqrt(DX*DX + DY*DY)), and output all clearly indicate a distance calculation, proving zero attempt was made on the grade calculator problem.

evidence.note: The code reads coordinates and calculates distance instead of reading a single grade and calculating a letter.

misconceptions.name: Complete task mismatch - wrong problem solved
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a distance calculator program instead of a grade calculator. The code solves an entirely different problem from what was assigned.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a different assignment or misunderstood which problem to solve.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 requires reading a numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges. The submitted code calculates the distance between two 2D points instead.
symptoms: Program reads four doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade
Program calculates distance using Euclidean formula instead of checking grade ranges
Output shows distance instead of letter grade
No conditional logic for grade boundaries exists
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for a completely different problem (possibly Q4 or another assignment), suggesting either confusion about which file to submit, a mix-up in file management, or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment requirements carefully. You need to: (1) read one integer grade, (2) use if-else statements to check ranges (90-100→A, 80-89→B, etc.), and (3) output the letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code is objectively solving a different problem (distance calculation) than the assigned problem (grade categorization). This is not a misconception about a specific concept but rather a complete mismatch between submission and assignment.

evidence.note: Student declares four coordinate variables and a distance variable, which is appropriate for distance calculation but completely wrong for grade calculation.
Program prompts for coordinates instead of a grade, demonstrating submission of wrong problem solution.

evidence.snippet:
DISTANCE = Math.sqrt(DX * DX + DY * DY);
      
      System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + DISTANCE);
evidence.note: Code calculates and outputs distance between points using Euclidean formula, not letter grade based on ranges.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program that computes the Euclidean distance between two points rather than reading a numeric grade and outputting the corresponding letter grade as specified in the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this question by writing a program that reads coordinates for two points and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, the program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and use conditional logic to print the appropriate letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the given ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x and y coordinates instead of a single grade value
No conditional logic based on grade ranges
Output describes the distance between two points rather than a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have confused this problem with a different assignment (distance between two points) or reused code from another question without adapting it to the grade-calculator requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and design the program around the required input (a single grade 0–100) and output (the correct letter grade based on the specified ranges). Replace the distance calculation code with if/else-if conditions that map the numeric grade to A, B, C, D, or F.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure, variable names, prompts, and output are all focused on point coordinates and distance, with no mention of grades or letter outputs.

evidence.note: All logic pertains to reading coordinates and computing distance; there is no handling of a numeric grade or letter grade mapping as required by the assignment.

misconceptions.name: Solved wrong problem (Distance Calculator instead of Grade Calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points, which is completely irrelevant to the assigned task of creating a Grade Calculator based on numeric input and fixed bounds.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student misunderstood the assignment or submitted code for a different question (Q3 Distance instead of Q3 Grade Calculator).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional logic to map it to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).

Code implements the distance formula (Math.sqrt(DX*DX + DY*DY)).
No conditional logic (if/else if/else) is present to determine letter grades.
